Possibly when he first composed this passage he was unacquainted with the story told in 6. 19, or at least had not incorporated it in his own work—the last three Books being of earlier composition.

ta\s dio/dous ta\s e)s ta\s korufa\s . . ferou/sas: the occupation of these passes might be for the purpose of preventing the Greeks from attacking the camp in the rear, or to obtain touch with Ephesos and the road to Sardes, in case a retreat became necessary.

Mykale (as seen from the south on a fine April morning) is a grand mountain range, culminating in twin korufai/, east and west (4130 ft. and 3966 ft. in height respectively), with a gentle slope down to the western point, where the promontory becomes involved in the outline of Samos.

toi=si kai\ katedo/keon. This dative is puzzling. The normal construction is with accus. and infinitive. Valckenaer wished to insert e)neo/n. Baehr takes doke/ein = existimare, kata/ in comp. contra aliquem, the dative being constructed with verbs compounded with kata/ (though never anywhere else with katadoke/ein). Stein explains the dative as used by analogy with suneide/nai (and compares katakri/nein tini/ ti 2. 133, 17. 146. 6). Kuehner, Gr. Gr. § 568. 1, ap. Baehr renders: sie glaubten bei ihnen, dass sie Neuerungen machten. neoxmo/n: cp. c. 104. 7 infra, neoxmou=n 4. 201, 5. 19.

duna/mios e)pilabome/noisi, “if occasion offered,” Rawlinson; “if they found the occasion,” Macaulay. du/namis as ‘potentiality,’ possibility, is remarkable in Hdt. The participle is here conditional. With the phrase cp. profa/sios e)pilabe/sqai 3. 36, 6. 49; also Plato Rep. 360 D ei)/ tis toiau/ths ecousi/as e)pilabo/menos ktl.
proefula/ssonto, ‘took precantions against beforehand,’ cp. 7. 176 supra; in the active more naturally of place, (ne/a) th\n profula/ssousan e)pi\ *skia/qw| 8. 92 supra.

au)toi\ de\ sfi/si. The exact relation of this e(/rkos of ge/rra to the e(/rkos kai\ li/qwn kai\ cu/lwn in c. 97 supra is problematical. The former is the fortified camp, from which all suspicious characters have been removed (or rendered innocuous); the ‘rampart of shields’ actually reappears in c. 102 infra; and we may suppose that here the Persians are drawn up, outside their camp, and have fixed their shields in the ground to act as a screen; but if they have advanced out beyond their fortified camp, all the more inexplicable does it appear that they should have allowed the Greeks to effect a landing without dispute, while the Greeks at their leisure landed, and drew up in battle-array, and then advanced to the attack.
On the ge/rra cp. c. 61 supra.

fh/mh te e)se/ptato kai\ khrukh/ion e)fa/nh. The Fama is plainly in Hdt.'s belief supernatural, as he explains; of the khrukh/ion, a more material tekmh/rion, he takes no further account. What became of this khrukh/ion? How many persons saw it? Was it the supernatural bearer of the supernatural message? Alas! that so much should be made of the impalpable fh/mh and nothing said of the subsequent history of the ocular sign! This omission is a weak spot in the story, in the argument; and nowadays, in a world of telepathy, crystal-gazing, subliminal selves, and other scientific enchantments, which explain the fh/mh to perfection, one is bound to take cognisance of the total disappearance of the material evidence.

A fh/mh which Hdt. treats as in no way supernatural had run right through the medizing Greek army in Boiotia a few weeks before, cp. c. 17 supra; it had proved a fraud; had it turned out to be true, it might have been regarded as divine.

Diodoros 11. 35 (Ephoros), cp. Polyain. 1. 33, completely rationalizes the story of this fh/mh, regarding it as a ruse by Leotychidas; Larcher and Thirlwall approve. A somewhat similar case was the fraud of Agesilaos in 394 B.C., which no doubt helped him to win the battle of Koroneia (Xenoph. Hell. 4. 3. 10-14), when he announced the defeat of the Lakedaimonian fleet off Knidos to his army as a victory; but he had received actual despatches, and had no need to pretend a synchronism. If a few days' interval occurred between the victory in Boiotia and the victory in Ionia the fh/mh is simple enough. If there was a real synchronism between the battles of Plataia and Mykale, then one of three or four alternatives can alone be true: either (a) the fh/mh was a fraud, a ruse, a gennai=on yeu=dos at the moment, which afterwards proved to be true to fact; or (b) it was in truth supernatural, supernormal, whether you explain it by direct divine interposition or by abnormally heightened human feeling; or (c) thirdly, it is an element of afterthought, a product of tradition, an embellishment of the facts, possibly traceable to excited hopes and feelings of the actual day, but without the adequate or full basis of fact asserted by the pious tradition. There is so much of this kind of thing in the story of the war that it does not appear unreasonable to ascribe the fh/mh motif, though it rings out more precisely and positively than any other, to the same creative faculty. There was some Homeric precedent for it, though the word fh/mh does not occur in the Iliad at all (pace Aischines § 141, cp. D. B. Monro, Odyssey XIII.-XXIV. p. 427), for the o)/ssa e)k *dio/s (Od. 1. 282) is its precursor. The word ei)se/ptato occurs Il. 21. 494 of the flight of a bird, to which is likened the motion of a goddess (Artemis).

h( de\ f. dih=lqe/ sfi w(=de: sc. to\ strato/pedon. The exact terms of the fh/mh are very nearly identical with the message (a)ggeli/h) which had reached the Greeks at the Heraion in front of Plataia that same day, o(/ti ma/xh te ge/gone kai\ nikw=|en oi( meta\ *pausani/ew c. 69 supra. The imperf. pres. nikw=|en here of the fait accompli (cp. gegone/nai ni/khn c. 101 infra) is remarkable; Xenoph. Hell. 4. 3. 1 has nikw=|en (but 4. 3. 10 o(/ti h(tthme/noi ei)=en); Stein compares nika=n in c. 48 supra, and interprets ‘are victors’ (Sieger seien). The use of nika=n there absolutely is easier than nikw=|en here with a direct object. Might it be one of Hdt.'s imperfects, of an action the result of which is abiding, or continuous? The passage in Xenophon shows that we need not read nenikw=|en here. e)n *boiwtoi=si is purely geographical.

dh=la dh\ ta\ qei_a tw=n prhgma/twn: “many things prove to me that the gods take part in the affairs of men,” Rawlinson; “now by many signs is the divine power seen in earthly things,” Macaulay. But the passage involves a classification of ‘things,’ into ta\ qei=a and ta\ mh\ qei=a, rather than the general assertion of the existence of “a divinity that shapes our ends, rough hew them as we will.” Cp. c. 65 supra. Hdt. is here a ‘dualist’: far from the formula of Thales, pa/nta plh/rh qew=n, but close to ‘common sense,’ or ‘popular philosophy,’ as we know it. Hdt.'s argument is not very closely expressed; the particnlar instance (ei) kai\ to/te) cannot prove the general (polloi=si tekmhri/oisi). But the formal statement here is not the real statement. The true predicate lies in ta\ qei=a: what is plain, by many infallible proofs, among them par exemple the particular case quoted, is the fact that some things are qei=a, that ‘miracles do happen’— though, of course, most happenings are quite ordinary and natural. (There are even degrees in the class, cp. 7. 137 tou=to/ moi e)n toi=si qeio/taton fai/netai gene/sqai, 8. 65 qei=on to\ fqeggo/menon, 8. 94 qei=on to\ prh=gma.) Cp. Introduction, § 11.

th=s au)th=s h(me/rhs sumpiptou/shs: the expression is somewhat clumsy—a day cannot coincide with itself—but the meaning is plain: the day, or date, of the action at Plataia and the date of the action just about to take place at Mykale was identically the same; but it was ‘the actions,’ not ‘the day,’ which coincided. sumpi/ptontos or sumpipto/ntwn would certainly be clearer (cp. App. Crit.): but is Hdt. always quite clear in thought or expression? trw=ma: cp. c. 90 supra. tau/th|: sc. e)n *muka/lh|.

to/de e(/teron sune/pese geno/menon, ‘a second coincidence occurred as follows.’ The expression again is not quite accurate: it takes two items to make a coincidence, and only one item is here expressed. Again, the coincident ‘occurrences’ are the ‘existence’ of two shrines of Demeter, one at Plataia and one at Mykale; but, strictly speaking, the existence of the shrines is not the occurrence, but rather the battles by the shrines.
sumbola/s, of ‘hostile meeting,’ as in 4. 159, 6. 120, 7. 210, etc.
w(s kai\ pro/tero/n moi ei)/rhtai: a definite cross-reference back to cc. 57, 62, 65 supra.
gegone/nai de\ ni/khn: this appears as equivalent to nikw=|en c. 100 supra; cp. also c. 69 supra.

o)rqw=s sfi h( fh/mh sune/baine e)lqou=sa, ‘the rumour which (had) reached them turned out to be true,’ or ‘they discovered the truth of the rumour which had reached them.’ The exact force of sune/baine here is disputable: its repetition just below, and in a slightly different sense, is by no means un-Herodotean.

prwi\ e)/ti th=s h(me/rhs. The adv. prwi/ is not found elsewhere in Hdt. Homer (Il. 8. 530 etc.), Xenophon (Hell. 1. 1. 30 e(ka/sths h(me/ras prw\| kai\ pro\s e(spe/ran) and other good writers use it = mane, explained by Theophrastos Fr. 6. 1. 9 as the forenoon, from a/natolh/ to meshmbri/a. But it is also used more generally, cp. Thuc. 4. 6. 1, etc. e)/ti is not = h)/dh but used with comparative force.
peri\ dei/lhn, ‘about evening,’ cp. 8. 6, 9, a passage which proves that the term admits of degrees. Here, in opposition to prwi/, it may mean merely p.m.

o(/ti de\ th=s au)th=s h(me/rhs sune/baine gi/nesqai. Hdt.'s predication again is not quite clear. The grammatical subject of oune/baine may be to\ e)n *muka/lh| (sc. trw=ma), or the two (sc. a)mfo/tera, or ta\ trw/mata), dh=la perhaps favouring this view: sune/baine gi/nesqai is, however, a simple and constant form for an occurrence, or event, taking place.

mhno/s te tou= au)tou= is a very frigid addition. Or would Hdt., then, have regarded it as possible for two events to take place on the same day in different months? But it is a thousand pities that he did not happen to give us the Attic date, by month, and day of the month, for the victory. If it had taken place in Boedromion, and about the time of the Eleusinia, would not tradition have more clearly emphasized the festive date?

The actual and precise day is given by Plutarch Aristeid. 19 as Boedromion 4 = Panemos 27, but in Camillus 19 and Mor. 349 F as Boedromion 3 < = Panemos 26>, a curious discrepancy. In any case the date may be that of the Charisteria, not of the battle. Hdt.'s data do not enable us to fix the date of the final battle at Plataia with precision. Busolt. Gr. Gesch. ii.2 (1895) 726, 742, places Plataia ‘at the beginning of August,’ and Mykale ‘about the middle of August,’ denying the synchronism. I should be inclined to admit the synchronism, or an approximate synchronism, and to place the battles somewhat later, early in September; cp. Appendix VII. § 6, VIII. § 2 (i.). The fact that other striking synchronisms are less trustworthy, cp. 7. 166 supra, does not entirely discredit this one. What is damaging to Hdt.'s credit as historian is the insistence on the synchronism, as a mere wonder, to the complete exclusion of its significance from a strategic point of view.

ou)/ti peri\ sfe/wn au)tw=n: this generous self-oblivion might at least attest the sense that strategically the
decisive blow in this campaign could not be struck by the fleet, nor could a check, or even a disaster to the fleet, matter so much. peri/ is used with the genitive similarly 8. 36 sfe/wn au)tw=n pe/ri e)fro/ntizon. For a)rrwdi/h cp. ibid.
tw=n *(ellh/nwn, ‘the Greeks at home’—h( *(ella/s ineludes themselves.

mh\ peri\ *mardoni/w| ptai/sh| h( *(ella/s: with the dative peri/ has primarily a locative force, and does not lose it even when locality ceases to be the prominent interest; the metaphor here (ptai/sh|) may be of shipwreck, but pro/s is the preposition more generally in use. Cp. Plato, Rep. 553 B e)/peita au)to\n i)/dh| e)cai/fnhs ptai/santa w)/sper pro\s e(/rmati pro\s th=| po/lei. The wrecking of Hellas on Mardonios might have been accomplished by battle, or by bribery, cp. c. 2 supra.
h( klhdw/n: cp. c. 91 supra; here the word = h( fh/mh, cp. c. 100 supra.
taxu/teron: qa=sson is not found in Hdt., nor taxu/tata
th\n pro/sodon, of a hostile advance, advance to the attack, as in 7. 223 (differently 6. 46). There is predicative force in the position of au(/th.

kai\ oi( ba/rbaroi e)/speudon: this assertion is of something quite new; hitherto the barbarians have not been anxious to fight. Now, however, they have drawn the Greeks to land, they have a fortified camp behind them, they have a corps d'armée somewhere about, if c. 96 supra is to be trusted, and they have apparently advanced and fixed their ge/rra as a e(/rkos before them (c. 99 supra); they still remained on the defensive though eager for the fray. Is the text here correct? Nothing corresponds to oi( me\n dh\ *(/ellhnes —oi( de\ ba/rbaroi with a contrasted verb to e)/speudon might originally have concluded the chapter.

w(/s sfi kai\ ai( nh=soi kai\ o( *(ellh/spontos a)/eqla proe/keito, ‘inasmuch as (seeing that) the islands and the Hellespont were the prizes at stake for them.’ w(s proe/keito is remarkable: w(s = e)pei/ (one might have expected w(s with participle, gen. abs.).

The Greeks and Persians at Mykale could hardly have taken this view of the case unless they had been already acquainted with the defeat of Mardonios. Were the Persians equally informed, by the fh/mh, or by an a)ggeli/h from Leotychidas, which, of course, they would not have believed; or, in fact, had sufficient time elapsed for the news to have reached Sardes as well as Samos? The islands would be those in proximity to Asia: the Kyklades were already free.

prosexe/si: for the word cp. c. 28 supra. The construction here with tetagme/noisi is quasi-adverbial; ep. e)pech=s tetagme/noi infra; the Korinthians, Sikyonians and Troizenians are intended, but the names are here withheld; they, with the Athenians, formed the left half, or flank, of the army. As they walk over the lower ground it seems that the Greeks have landed east of the Persian encampment.

e)n w(=|: sc. xro/nw|. e)/ti is perhaps a corruption, or remainder of a lost word
(e)timwre/onto, or e)/tuxon protere/ontes). Stein takes kai\ dh/ as it stands to be = h)/dh.
e(/ws ta\ ge/rra: the shields have been erected in c. 99 ad f.
ou)de\n e)/lasson ei)=xon: cp. c. 70 supra (ple/on ei)=xon). Only Persians appear engaged.
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn kai\ tw=n prosexe/wn o( strato/s: treated as quite a distinct and separate unit, or rather army, or corps d'armée; the names are still withheld.

o(/kws e(wutw=n kai\ mh\ *lakedaimoni/wn: the negative mh( shows that this is given as in the minds of the Athenians; it is, indeed, a genuine motif of Athenian legend and oratory, and in the hands of Isokrates (cp. Hdt. IV.-VI. ii. 194 f.) became a guide to the reconstruction of the past. It betrays, or suggests, the character of the source from which Hdt. has drawn the story of Mykale: Athenian, or philAthenian.
parakeleusa/menoi, ‘encouraging each other with shouts,’ cp. 8. 15. e)/rgou ei)/xonto, cp. 8. 11 supra.
h)/dh, ‘at once.’
e(teroiou=to to\ prh=gma, ‘the affair took a fresh turn, aspect’; cp. 7. 225 supra.

diwsa/menoi ga\r ta\ ge/rra: this phrase marks the second stage in the struggle; they pushed their way through the rampart of Persian shields — or pushed the shields apart, so as to open a way for themselves—and then charged (fero/menoi) en masse (a(le/es) on the Persians behind the shields, who had doubtless been plying them with arrows. diwqe/esqai in a more general sense, c. 88 supra.
oi)\ de/: the de/ is demonstrative, or emphatic; the sentence might otherwise have been relative.
xro/non suxno\n a)muno/menoi te/los e)/feugon = xr. s. h)munonto te/los de\ e)/feugon. A rather lax use of the present, or imperfect, participle.
*)aqhnai=oi de\ kai\ *kori/nqioi kai\ *sikuw/nioi kai\ *troizh/nioi: at last, when the victory is won, the other contingents on the left wing are expressly named, besides the Athenians.

h)=san . tetagme/noi: how little this construction is a mere temporal pluperfect appears from this passage; they were, what they had been all along, ranged e)pech=s *)aqhnai/oisi, in the given order (ou(/tw).

sunepispo/menoi sunese/pipton: they entered the fortified camp en masse (i.e. without breaking from one another), and at the same time as the Persians, whom they were pursuing, i.e. pursuers and pursued all entered together. sunese/pipton, by the way, throws some light
upon its correlate sunece/pipton as in 5. 22.

w(s de\ kai\ to\ tei=xos a)rai/rhto marks the third stage in the combat, or rather its culmmation. The pluperfect is hardly temporal, for the fighting is not yet all over. pro\s a)lkh\n tre/pesqai (cp. a)lkh=s memnh=sqai c. 70 supra) is just the opposite of e)s fugh\n tre/pesqai, cp. c. 63 supra, 8. 91, etc.
oi( ba/rbaroi: did no Greeks strike a blow on this occasion upon the Persian side? Cp. c. 103. 8 infra.
pro\s fugh/n te o(rme/ato: so in Thuc. 4. 14. 1 tw=n a)ndrw=n e)s fugh\n w(rmhme/nwn, of actual or literal physical movement.
kat' o)li/gous gino/menoi, “forming into small knots,” Blakesley; the preposition has distributive force, cp. 8. 113 supra e)cele/geto kat' o)li/gous.

toi=si ai)ei\ e)spi/ptousi might seem hardly consistent with sunepispo/menoi sunese/pipton above (the imperfect notwithstanding); but that phrase was obviously rhetorical, this is both more accurate and more ‘elegant.’
*)artau+/nths: cp. 8. 130 supra, c. 107 infra.
*)iqami/trhs: cp. 8. 130 supra.

*tigra/nhs: cp. c. 96 supra. His death is really the first clear intimation in the story of the actual presence at Mykale of any of the six myriads, of which he is there put in command: is it sufficient to convince us that any part of the corps d'armée was present, or engaged in the battle, or that the battle was more than an engagement between the Greek forces, from the fleet, and the Medo-Persian Epibatai from the king's fleet — the only portion of the navy, probably, which could be trusted to show fight, especially on land? Athenian or phil-Attic tradition has exaggerated the battle of Mykale into a grand piece to match the synchronous battle in Boiotia; cp. c. 106 infra. Tigranes, if killed on this occasion, was perhaps in command of the Persian Epibatai; cp. c. 96 supra.

e)/ti de/. It is only at the fourth stage of the fight that the Lakedaimonians and their half of the army arrive on the scene, and help to finish the remnant (ta\ loipa\ sundiexei/rizon). Hdt. does not employ the simpler forms xeiri/zein or diaxeiri/zein, nor any one else the double compound.
suxno/s = pollo/s, polu/s: cp. c. 102 supra, et passim.

*peri/lews: the name Perilaos was common and widespread, i.e. there is nothing specially Sikyonian, or even Peloponnesian about it. (Cp. PapeBenseler, sub v.) Nothing more is recorded of this man: the absence of a patronymic suggests that Hdt. did not get this item from an inscription, least
of all in Sikyon. Samian or Athenian tradition may have preserved the bare name of the only general who fell on this occasion.

tw=n te *sami/wn: this great, though somewhat vague, service of the Samians is very lightly and easily introduced; in fact Hdt. has nothing concrete or definite to report on their behalf. oi( strateuo/menoi, cp. 7. 61 supra. e)n tw=| stratope/dw|, not necessarily e)n tw=| tei/xei, cp. c. 15 supra. But what of the Samians on the Greek side, of whom there should now have been some? Or were there as yet no Samians serving? Cp. c. 92 supra.
a)parairhme/noi ta\ o(/pla, ‘deprived of their heavy arms,’ ep. c. 99 supra. a)paire/ein takes double acc., cp. 8. 3 supra.
au)ti/ka kat' a)rxa/s: cp. 7. 88 supra; it would go better here with e)/rdon.
e(teralke/a: cp. 8. 11 supra.

e)/rdon o(/son e)dune/ato: the first verb is rather epic (cp. 7. 33 supra). What did they ‘do’? They might have set fire to the camp? or they might have pulled it partially to pieces; or they might have ‘done sacrifice’: but this testimonial lacks precision.
proswfele/ein with the dative Stein regards as ‘poetical’; it is used with the acc. c. 68 supra in a more precise or definite context.
oi( a)/lloi *)/iwnes: not including the Milesians, as the next c. shows. There were thus Ionians besides the Samians and the Milesians serving with the Persians; they would be the crews of the ships.
a)/rcantas: i.e. au)ti/ka kat' a)rxa\s e)/rdontas o(/son e)dune/ato.

a)posta/ntes a)po\ *perse/wn: this phrase is hardly to be taken in the physical sense, suggested by the immediate eontext, viz. stood off, separated from the Persians there and then, but rather in the political sense: threw off their allegiance to Persia. The absence of the article and the last sentence of the next c. support this view. Cp. c. 90 supra.

e)pe/qento toi=si barba/roisi. This attack on the barbarians goes beyond anything explicitly recorded of the Samians in the context, but it still leaves something to be desired, in the way of concrete definiteness. Rawlinson ad l. remarks that “Hdt. is never very favourable to the Ionian Greeks and may have given them on this occasion less credit than they deserved.” Euge! Diodoros (Ephoros) is kinder; cp. Appendix VII. § 7 (c), 2. Had Hdt. written the story of Mykale before his visit to Samos, where the fame of that island grew dearer to him (cp. 3. 60)? And did he leave what he had written unrevised?

*milhsi/oisi de\ prosete/takto: the pluperfect is in strict time; cp. c. 99 supra; but the two reasons already given, and here more explicitly repeated, are inconsistent with each other. If the Persians removed the Milesians to prevent their creating a disturbance, a mutiny, or at least some trouble in the camp, they distrusted their loyalty. If they distrusted their loyalty, they did not entrust to them the custody of the passes, or expect them to act as their
guides to safe places of retreat, in case of a disaster occurring, such as actually occurred.

a)/ra here, as frequently, may be taken to suggest the unexpected. The historian speaks propria persona in oi(=a/ per kate/labe: h)\n katalamba/nh| being of course future in foree. neoxmo/n (l. 6) is repeated from c. 99.
oi(\ de/: the demonstrative (article), with de/, resumes the subject of the sentence, and so lends it additional emphasis. Cp. note to 7. 51. 3, etc.
ai(\ dh/: the relative, emphasized.

to\ deu/teron *)iwni/h a)po\ *perse/wn a)pe/sth, ‘Ionia threw off the Persian yoke for the second time.’ (Cp. cc. 103, 90 supra.) This statement involves an implicit reference to the first or former revolt, and so might seem to take the record given in Bk. 5 for granted. But the fact of that revolt was no doubt notorious; Hdt. might even have found the revolt of 479 B.C. already noted as the deute/rh apo/stasis, and it is not even necessary to suppose this little sentence (or the words to\ deu/teron) a gloss, or an insertion of the second draft by the author, in order to reconcile it with the theory of the prior composition of Bks. 7-9. Cp. Introduction, §§ 7, 8.
h)ri/steusan *)aqhnai=oi, ‘the Athenians obtained the meed of valour.’ Cp. 8. 17 supra for the formula.

*(ermo/lukos o( *eu)qoi/nou. The father's name is corrupt in the best MSS.; cp. App. Crit. eu)qu/nou looks like a correction of eu)qo/nou. Euthynos is a commoner name at Athens than ‘Euthoinos,’ which is, however, found on Inscripp. ‘Hermolykos’ is mentioned again as pankratiast with a statue on the Akropolis (Pausan. 1. 23. 10). Whether this Hermolykos son of Euthoinos was any relation to Hermolykos son of Diitrephes, who dedicated a statue of his father (cp. Pausanias 1. 23. 3), apparently the general Diitrephes well known from Thucydides (7. 29. 1, 8. 64. 1), is a much debated question; cp. Frazei, Pausanias ii. 275 f., 289; Hitzig-Bluemner, Pausanias (1896), notes ad ll.c.

pagkra/tion e)paskh/sas, ‘who (had) practised (successfully? e)pi-) as a pankratiast.’ The pankration, a combination of boxing (pugmh/) and wrestling (pa/lh), was first introduced at Olympia in 648 B.C., Ol. 33, Pausan. 5. 8. 8; cp. Clinton, Fasti i. p. 198; and victories in the pankration are celebrated in several of Pindar's Epinikia: e.g. Nem. 2, 3, 5, Isth. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.

kate/labe u(/steron tou/twn: for the verb cp. cc. 93, 104 supra, ‘overtook.’ The general date places the event in the Pentekontaëteris, but unfortunately without a precise year. The war between ‘the Athenians’ and the Karystians is, however, presumably that one commemorated by Thuc. 1. 98. 3 about 472 B.C.; cp. Busolt, Gr. G. iii. (1897) 140.

e)n *ku/rnw|: this Kyrnos in Euboia, in the territory of Karystos, is not elsewhere mentioned. The nominal coincidence with the island Corsica (cp. 7. 165 supra) was not perhaps accidental. On Karystos cp. 8. 121 supra. On Geraistos, 8. 7 supra.

*kori/nqioi *troizh/nioi *sikuw/nioi: the order of merit differs slightly from their order in battle-array c. 102 supra, but all contingents on the left wing obtained prizes. The right (Lakedaimontans, etc.) was quite left in the shade. This story is hardly of Spartan origin.
e)pei/te katerga/santo, cum interfecissent (Baehr). They seem to have taken no prisoners on this occasion.
th\n lhi/hn proecagago/ntes, ‘though not until they (had) brought (led) out the spoil.’ It was apparently alive, at least some of it. Thuc. 2. 94. 3 a)n qrw/pous kai\ lei/an labo/ntes.
kai\ qhsaurou/s eu(=ron is not in strict construction. Stein regards it as an addition from the author's hand; cp. Introduction, § 9. xrh/mata apparently = money, but might cover plate.

a)pe/pleon. Obviously the Greek forces at Mykale had not defeated, had not even encountered, the corps d'armée accredited to Tigranes c. 96 supra; had they done so, the road to Sardes was once more open to them. The battle of Mykale was evidently a pro/skrousma braxu\ toi=s barba/rois, a raid, a brilliant raid no doubt, but not a great vietory, and the Greeks at once retired, before the Persian land-forces came up, and abandoned the mainland to its fate.

peri\ a)nasta/sios th=s *)iwni/hs. At Samos, after their return from Mykale, the Hellenes, i.e. the naval Synedrion, ep. c. 90 supra, discussed the question of ‘the evaeuation of Ionia.’ This was an old idea, started by Bias of Priene, if 1. 170 may be trusted; some of the Ionians (in 546 B.C.) th\n doulosu/nhn ou)k a/nexo/menoi e)ce/lipon ta\s patri/das (1. 169). Again in 494 B.C. a few voluntarily (6. 17) and still more against their will (6. 20) had left their homes for ever. A migration en masse had recently been recommended to Athens by the Delphic oracle (7. 140 supra), and brought within the range of practical politics by Themistokles (8. 62 supra). There was thus a good deal in the recent experience of the Greeks, not to speak of the migrations and colonizations of earlier days, to make a wholesale flitting no absurd or unpractical idea. For the use of a)na/stasis cp. Thuc. 2. 14. 2 (of the flitting of the Athenians from the country into the city 431 B.C.), 7. 75. 1 tou= strateu/matos (of the break-up and departure before Syracuse in 413 B.C.), 1. 133 ad f. e)k tou= i(erou= (of the retirement from the temple by a suppliant). Cp. 4. 115
supra fe/rete e)canaste/wmen e)k th=s gh=s th=sde.

o(/kh| th=s *(ella/dos th=s au)toi\ e)gkrate/es h)=san. If Ionia was to be evacuated and abandoned to the ‘barbarians,’ some place for the Ionians would have to be found on Hellenic soil. This problem appears to take the control or possession of Hellas proper (or the greater part of it) for granted; it assumes the truth of the fh/mh of the day before (a night will presuniably have intervened); or has the fh/mh (of c. 100) by this time been officially confirmed by despatches to Samos? Or may this deliberation be taken as an undesigned confession that the victory in Boiotia had been fully reported to the Greeks at Samos or ever they advanced on Mykale? *(ella/s here comes very nearly to ‘Greece’ in our sense of the word. e)gkrath\s is used similarly 8. 49 supra. The imp. indic. h)=san is remarkable; = eisi( l.c.
prokath=sqai: as in 8. 36 supra, and cp. also 7. 172.
to\n pa/nta xro/non, ‘for ever,’ c. 73. 3.
mh/ as in a conditional sentence (participial).

xai/rontas pro\s tw=n *perse/wn a)palla/cein, ‘will get off with impunity (go unpunished) at the hands of Persia.’ Cp. 3. 69 ou)/toi min dei= xai/ronta a)palla/ssein. The negative is more usually combined with xai/rwn, e.g. 3. 29 a)ta/r toi u(mei=s ge ou) xai/rontes ge/lwta e)me\ qh/sesqe, Xenoph. Anab. 5. 6. 32 diaspasqe/ntes d' a)\n ou)/te xai/rontes a)\n a)palla/caite.

*peloponnhsi/wn me\n toi=si e)n te/lei+ e)ou=si: primarily Leotychidas, the Spartan king and navarch, and in the second line the captains of the Korinthians, Sikyonians, Troizenians. Two points raise suspicion: (i.) Could the king or the Synedrion have decided off-hand so immense and far-reaching a question? (ii.) Would the Dorian states at least have desired to reinforce the ‘Ionian’ element in Central Hellas, and in Peloponnese itself, by supporting such a proposal? oi( e)n te/lei+ as in 3. 18, Thuc. 1. 10. 4 e)/cw tw=n basile/wn kai\ tw=n ma/lista e)n te/lei, 5. 47. 9 oi( ta\ te/lh e)/xontes (offieial term at Elis), 1. 58. 1 ta\ te/lh tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, cp. 4. 15. 1, etc.
e)do/kee: a strict imperfect; the doke/on did not become a do/gma.

tw=n mhdisa/ntwn e)qne/wn tw=n *(el.: a preliminary list of them has been given 7. 132 supra, but the list is not complete, omitting the Argives (cp. 8. 73) and some islanders (Andros, the Karystians, etc.).

ta\ †e)mpolai=a e)canasth/santas. The e)cana/stasis in this case was hardly to be accomplished without violence. e)mpolai=a is a conjectural emendation; cp. App. Crit. = e)mpo/ria. But the adj. e)mpolai=os is not common, and would mean (in the neuter) not ‘markets,’ but rather ‘commodities.’
dou=nai e)noikh=sai: exactly as in Thuc. 2. 27. 2 e)kpesou=si de\ toi=s *ai)ginh/tais oi( *lakedaimo/nioi e)/dosan *qure/an oi)kei=n. (Exegetical and telic, or gerundive.)

a)rxh/n, ‘at all’—in the first instance; they moved in fact the
previous question, and had also a formal or constitutional objection to urge, viz. against interferenee between a metropolis and its colonies. The metropolitan claim of Athens had been recognized and urged from the other side as early as 498 B.C., cp. 5. 97—and probably dated back at least to the days of Peisistratos (cp. c. 97 supra), but perhaps only referred to Miletos, and some of the mainland towns at first. It was, of eourse, a part of the basis of the Delian symmachy just afterwards, and was then perhaps more widely extended; cp. next note.

kai\ ou(/tw dh/: there might perhaps seem to be a non sequitur in these words, which throws doubt, not upon the fact here stated so much as upon the previous report of the debate in the Synedrion at Samos (cc. 90, 91). If Peloponnesians were not to be allowed bouleu/ein peri\ tw=n (*)attikw=n) a)poikie/wn— and yielded the point—the matriculation of the ‘Samians’ and ‘Chians’ (which appear on the Marmor Par. 27 as colonies from Athens) might seem to be inconsistent therewith. But was the Ionian settlement in Samos rightly ascribed to Athens? The Ionians of Samos were ultimately traced back to Epidauros; cp. Pausan. 7. 4. 2 (cp. *dwrie/es (sic) *)epidau/rioi Hdt. 1. 146). The ease of Chios is even more obscure; according to the native historian, Ion, a contemporary of Hdt.'s, the island was peopled by Abantes from Euboia (cp. Hdt. 1. 146), and by immigrants from Histiaia; their ‘Ionization’ they owed to a king Hektor, in the third generation after; but Ion failed to account for the Chians being reckoned Ionians (ou) me/ntoi e)kei=no/ ge ei)/rhke kaq' h(/ntina ai)ti/an *xi=oi telou=sin e)s *)/iwnas, Pausan. 7. 4. 10). Possibly Sainos and Chios, at least in 479 B.C., were not yet accounted ‘Athenian’ colonies; and even the passage in Hdt. 1. 146-7 distinguishes among the Ionians between oi( a)po\ tou= prutanhi/ou tou= *)aqhnai/wn o(rmhqe/ntes kai\ nomi/zontes gennaio/tatoi ei)=nai *)iw/nwn and the rest. (The passage in c. 147 making the Apaturia the test of Ionism admits that the Ephesians and Kolophonians did not observe it; but the passage is very like a gloss.) The Athenians might protest against any intervention between themselves and their settlements abroad, and yet allow the enrolment of Samos and Chios in the Hellenic alliance without a murmur, having (at this time at least) no metropolitan elaim over these islands any more than over the Aiolian Lesbos. But the whole story of the deliberations is, of course, highly suspicious; the proposed a)na/stasis would have meant a civil war, and the admirals could hardly have settled such a question.

kai\ tou\s a)/llous nhsiw/tas cannot refer to the islands enumerated in 8. 46 supra, for they already belonged to the Symmachy: the Greeks at Mykale, at Samos, at the Hellespont (cp. c. 114 infra) had Samians, Chians, Lesbians, and a good many other ‘nesiotes’ with them, sustrateuo/menoi toi=si *(/ellhsi (sic), who are eompletely ignored in the narrative of the aetual operations, and only come into account in this highly suspicious passage on diplomatic and constitutional points. ‘The Islands’ were understood to be half the prize of Mykale, e. 101 supra.

e)s to\ summaxiko\n e)poih/santo, ‘admitted them as members of the alliance’: to\ s. = tou\s summa/xous. Hdt. has summaxi/hn e)poih/sato 1. 77, po/lias u(p' e(wutoi=si e)poih/santo 5. 103. Cp. Thuc. 3. 3. 4 tou\s a)/ndras . .
e)s fulakh\n e)poih/santo, 8. 1. 3 ta\ tw=n cumma/xwn e)s a)sfa/leian poiei=sqai. But cp. App. Crit. The statement here may be reconciled with the statement in c. 92 supra by supposing that at Delos Hegesistratos and his two compamons only bound themselves to do their best to bring the Samians into the alliance; but the harmony is a little strained— especially considering that the allies have been to Samos once already (c. 96) in the interval.
pi/sti te kai\ o(rki/oisi, as in c. 92 supra.

e)mmene/ein te kai\ mh\ a)posth/sesqai: this formula seems to presuppose a cummaxi/a e)s a)ei/, e)s to\n pa/nta xro/non. The right of a)po/stasis is surrendered. The formula and the story may have been useful ‘precedents’ for the Delian alliance, which no doubt was equally unlimited in time (cp. *)aq. pol. 23. 5).

e)/pleon ta\s gefu/ras lu/sontes. Rawlinson (ad l.) suggests that the destruction of the bridges (8. 117) must have been already known (by Lesbians, for example) and that Hdt. has misconceived the motive of the move to the Hellespont, which was “only to reconnoitre.” The Greeks will have aimed at more than that—promoting revolt, cutting off remnants, and so on. But is it so certain that they knew the bridges were no more, or might not be restored?

a)pofugo/ntwn: kateilhqe/ntwn: e)o/ntwn: this string of participles is not elegant, but a)pof. is little more than an adjective; it might very well be dispensed with. kateilhqe/ntwn here seems to mean ‘crowded,’ ‘confined,’ ‘eooped up’; cp. 5. 119, 8. 27, cc. 31, 70 supra (kateilhme/noi). If there were so few of them, one would have thought Mykale roomy enough for them.
ta\ a)/kra t. *m. = ta\s korufa\s t. *m. cc. 104, 99 supra.
komidh/: cp. 8. 108 supra.

*masi/sths o( *darei/ou: he was full brother to Xerxes, cp. 7. 82 supra, and had been one of the six generals, or field-marshals, of the army in 480 B.C. It is odd to find him here a casual attaché of the naval forces, or of the corps d'armée in Ionia: nor is he! For he has a bodyguard, oi( dorufo/roi oi( *masi/stew infra; was he, not Tigranes, the real commander of the six myriads, c. 96 supra? If so, he was not present at the disaster which had just taken place (tw=| pa/qei) t. g.) but was probably coming to the support of the encampment at Mykale, and naturally fell foul of Artayntes (c. 102 supra).
gunaiko\s kaki/w: cp. c. 20 supra.
to\n basile/os oi)=kon: cp. 8. 102 supra, 5. 31.
a)kou=sai, ‘to be called . .’

de/nnos: the verb denna/zein occurs twice in Sophokles, Antig. 759, Aias
243, and in Euripides, Rhes. 925. It is found previously also in Theognis 1211. The substantive (reproach, taunt) is rare.
e)pei( polla\ h)/kouse, ‘when he had heard more than enough . .’
deina\ poieu/menos, ‘in a rage . .’
spa=tai e)pi\ to\n a)kina/khn, ‘draws his native sword upon Masistes,’ as we say. On a)kina/khs cp. 7. 54 supra.
frasqei/s (ubi animadvertit) seems less forcible than the Aldine fqa/s (praevertens), but both would be de trop.

*ceinago/rhs o( *prhci/lew. Prexileos, or Praxilas, is a very uncommon name, and nothing more is known of this Halikarnassian (Praxilla of Sikyon, Pausan. 3. 13. 5, is also unrivalled). Xeinagoras, or Xenagoras, is less rare. Of this man nothing more is known than is here by Hdt. recorded, but the record is significant: (a) There were Greeks with the Persian forces after Mykale: this man, to be sure, would be a subject of Artemisia (less probably an exile. or adventurer). (b) His appointment as ‘syennesis’ of Kilikia is remarkable, and probably the first instance of the investiture of a Greek subject with a Persian governorship. (c) This fact (which belongs to the history of the Pentekontaëteris) may be regarded as more certain than the cause or occasion alleged by Hdt. for it. (d) Nevertheless as himself a Halikarnassian Hdt. will have had special interest and information in regard to this fellow-citizen.

The predecessor of Xeinagoras in Kilikia was Syennesis, or the syennesis, son of Oromedon, mentioned 7. 98 supra, who according to Aischyl. Pers. 326 lost his life at the battle of Salamis, leaving presumably no son to succeed him. This Halikarnassian may have founded a dynasty in Kilikia: the next governor of Kilikia known to history is the ‘syennesis’ of the Anabasis; cp. l.c. supra. (Rawlinson ventures to say that “Xeinagoras can only have occupied a subordinate position”: thus indirectly charging Hdt. in this case with a serious and apparently wilful exaggeration of his fellow-citizen's greatness. Krueger's emendation shifts the venue to Lykia.)
a(rpa/zei me/son: cp. Terent. Ad. 3. 2. 18 sublimem medium arriperem et capite pronum in terram statuerem.
e)caei/ras is here quite literally intended; cp. Xenoph. Kyr. 2. 4. 14 sunarpa/sas e)ch=|re, Aristoph. Knights 1359 a)/ras mete/wron ei)s to\ ba/raqron e)mbalw= (Valckenaer).
tau=ta e)rga/sato xa/rita tiqe/menos: xa/rin ti/qesqai, cp. c. 60 supra: an inverted predication (= tau=ta e)rgazo/menos xa/rin e)ti/qeto).

ou)de\n e)pi\ ple/on tou/twn a mere
confession of ignorance! For the formula cp. c. 41 supra. One would like to know what happened to Artayntes.

div2.p: There follows here, by way of digression (cc. 108-113), a story of the King's Amour, or the Death of Masistes, which exhibits Hdt. at his best. A story could hardly be better told, or present more artfully the elements of a domestic tragedy, of a palace intrigue, started in passion and jealousy, culminating in torture, rebellion, death. One great defect the story, indeed, has from the moral point of view: it is the innocent who suffer, or who suffer most; the guilty king, the jealous and cruel queen, come off scot free. Two considerations may slightly relieve this objection from an aesthetic standpoint: Artaynta, the daughter of Masistes, has a good deal to answer for: she is the root of the mischief. Again, ‘rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft,’ and Masistes and his sons die with arms in their hands against the king. But it eannot be said that Hdt. makes anything of these motifs. As a historian he might plead (though it is not his way!) that the faets were as he stated them, painfully immoral. and aesthetically distressing. As a moralist he might plead that the true moral lay outside the story, in the suggestion of all that Hellas had been spared by the successful resistanee to the Oriental despot, which had made such tragedies, possible in tyrants' houses, for ever impossible in Hellas! And, again, that he thus dismisses Xerxes, to go to his own place, the scorn and derision of all good men, with his lawless passions and his slavish submission to ‘the law of the Medes and Persians,’ his childish vanities (h(sqei\s periba/lletai) and his prodigal pleasures (h(sqei\s de\ kai\ tau/th|), his humorous caprices (speeches to Masistes) and his capricious wrath (qumwqei/s). The dramatic narrative falls into five acts.
(i.) The scene in Sardes: Xerxes' passion for his brother Masistes' wife: her faithfulness and virtue! and the king's ruse to win her, by wedding his son Dareios to her daughter.
(ii.) The scene shifts to Susa: the king's still fouler transfer of his affections from his brother's wife to his son's wife, Artaynta.
(iii.) The fatal gift: the robe of Amestris the queen: her jealousy and error: destruction to the wife of Masistes, the mother of Artaynta!
(iv.) The king's birthday feast: the queen's request: the despot's involuntary humiliation.
(v.) The catastrophe: wreck of the house of Masistes. (Masistes rejects the king's overtures: the mutilation of his wife: the rebellion, and its defeat.)
It is an omission that Artaynta does not expressly share the fate of her family.

This story might almost rank with the Hebrew story of Esther as an illustration of life at the Persian court. But, except for the external referenee above indicated, it lacks the national and popular setting, the political purpose, and therewith the ethical contents, which ennoble the Jewish tale. The Greek interest in this tale is purely reflexive. No Greek, whether man or woman, figures in this drama: the virtues of the wife of Masistes are purely domestic; her husband as the a)nh\r a)gaqo/s, good man, husband, father, and yet rebel withal, prepared to work ‘no end of ill’ to the king, his brother, umtes to some extent the rôles of Mordecai and Haman; the king himself cuts no great figure in either tale, but here he is less of a puppet and more of a curse, while behind and over all rises the terrible figure of Amestris, ‘a fury slinging flame,’ a barbarian fiend incarnate. (If Ahasuerus = Xerxes, Esther would = Amestris. But that cannot be, “if we accept the stories which Hdt. tells of Amestris,” and which the Jews tell of Esther.)

div3.p: e)n de\ th=|si *sa/rdisi: cp. 8. 117 supra; it is, however, a question whether Xerxes was in Sardes at this time, and not rather engaged, in upper Asia, in the reduction of the revolted satrapy of Babylon; cp. C. F. Lehmann, ‘Xerxes und die Babylonier,’ Wochensch. f. Klass. Philologie, 1900, 959-965, Ed. Meyer, G.d.A. iii. p. xiv.; Appendix VII. § 2.

e)tu/gxane e)w/n marks a coincidence, which is not causally related to the antecedents, or rather concomitants. Xerxes, as we are here given to understand, spent the winter of 480-79 B.C., and at least the whole of the ensuing
summer, in Sardes, presumably awaiting the issue of the campaign in Greece. Aischylos (Persai) makes Xerxes return direct from Athens to Susa.
fugw/n accepts the representation of the king's return as a fugh/.
to/te dh/: at the time of the battle of Mykale; or perhaps more generally throughout the period from his return to the battle of Mykale.
a)/ra: cp. c. 104. 3 supra. a)/ra h)/ra looks unfortunate. Stein compares the position of a)/ra here and in c. 9 supra and in 4. 134 (i.e. construes it with e)n th=|si *sa/rdisi e)w/n?).

th=s *masi/stew gunaik<*>s: that this lady is anonymous in the story does not make for its credit. Was she possibly, like her daughter, an *)artau+/nth, and possibly again a relative, a sister, of the Artayntes who has figured above? Masistes apparently throughout has only one wife. She had not accompanied her lord on the march to Greece (cp. 7. 187), but had probably come down to meet him on his return to Sardes with Xerxes.
prospe/mponti: sc. a/gge/lous The subject of e)du/nato may be h( gunh/ (van H. takes it to be to\ e)pequ/mei).
promhqeo/menos, ‘out of respect for . .’; a genitive might be expected.
ei)=xe, ‘supported,’ ‘upheld.’
eu)= ga/r ktl., ‘for she well knew that violence would not be employed against her.’
e)rgo/menos is middle; cp. 7. 197. 21 supra.

to\n ga/mon tou=ton refers to the following qugate/ra. The verb prh/ssei has, perhaps, a suggestion of intrigue: he indeed was hoping still to get hold of the mother (la/myesqai = lh/yesqai: cp. Smyth, Ionic § 130, p. 136).

*darei/w|: this Dareios was the eldest son, and on the assassination of his father in 465 B.C was falsely accused of the crime, and executed by his youngest brother Artaxerxes; Ktesias, Pers. 29; Gilmore, p. 158 f. Had all this happened when this story was first contrived?
e)s *sou=sa: the scene shifts to the capital; cp. 8. 99, 7. 151 supra, and 5. 54.

h)ga/geto: the middle is generally used of the bridegroom, here of the father-in-law. This word marks the actual marriage; the practices (prh/ssei) and the performances of the usual rites (ta\ nomizo/mena poih/sas), at Sardes previously, only amounted to a betrothal (a(rmo/sas). The crown-prince lives apparently in his father's palace, even after his marriage: is this improbable?

ou(/tw dh\ e)pe/pauto: this pluperfect is plainly rhetorical, and not used of strict temporal sequence. o(\ de/: the subject is re-expressed, and the de/ attached, for the sake of emphasis; cp. c. 106. 7 supra.

diameiya/menos h)/ra, ‘transferred his affections’: perhaps the dia- (in comp.) marks the completeness of the change, h)/ra te kai\ e/tu/gxane the rapidity of his success. For tugxa/nein cp. 5. 23 (e(/tuxe), and teucome/nh supra, teu/cesqai c. 109 infra.

*)artau(/nth: the mere identity of name with Artayntes, c. 107 supra, is not, of course, sufficient to prove any connexion between the house of Masistes and that of his colleague and foeman; but the name is of ill-omen for the house anyway—and perhaps for that reason the daughter of Masistes bears it.

xro/nou de\ proio/ntos: an interval occurs a)na/pusta gi/netai: cp. 6. 64 e)/dee de\ w(s e)/oike a)na/pusta geno/mena tau=ta katapau=sai *dhma/rhton th=s basilhi/hs. The moment of ‘discovery’ is fateful.

*)/amhstris h( *ce/rcew gunh/: she hardly requires the description after 7. 61, 114 supra; but this passage is, of course, independent of those, the second, indeed, of which is of later composition than this (and the former, perhaps, a gloss).

fa=ros qe/hs a)/cion: the hardiest advocate of the extension of Hdt.'s autopsy, and first-hand authority in general, will hardly venture to argue from this phrase that Hdt. had actually seen this plaid or pall: why then press the phrase elsewhere? Cp. cc. 25, 70 supra.
h(sqei\s h(sqei/s: such are a despot's ‘pleasures’! Cp. note to c. 108 supra. There is some humour, perhaps, in the repetition.
a)nti\ tw=n au)tw=| u(pourghme/nwn, ‘in return for her services to him’; cp. u(pourge/ein 8. 110, xrhsta\ u(pourge/ein 8. 143, u(pourgh/sein 7. 38 (of the despot himself).
teu/cesqai is absolute (‘shall obtain her request’). pa/nta with ai)th/sasan, ‘whatever she asked,’ even if she asked everything.

th=| de\ kakw=s ga\r e)/dee panoiki/h| gene/sqai: the de/ is of course misplaced (unless we were to read h(\ de/). panoiki/h|, 7. 39. e)/dee kakw=s gene/sqai is the coldest of fatalistic formulae; cp. 5. 33. It does not clearly appear what the fate of this woman was.
pa=n ma=llon doke/wn ktl.: cp. 7. 38 supra.
a)dew=s, ‘confidently,’ sure of the result.
pantoi=os e)gi/neto: cp. 7. 10. 30.

e)peureqh=|: his detection would follow upon (e)p-) her previous (pri/n) suspicions, strong (kat-) suspicions: the dative participle kateikazou/sh| is observable: a dat. of the agent, instead of u(po/ with genitive; cp. Madvig § 38 g (p. 37) —where the instances leave much to be desired.
prh/sswn refers here to decided malpractices! Cp. c. 108.
po/lis: cp. the assignment of the city of Anthylla to the wife of the Satrap of Egypt for ‘shoe-money,’ 2. 98; the assignations to Themistokles, Thuc. 1. 138. 5, etc.
e)di/dou, ‘offered,’ kept offering, a strong imperf.; cp. 8. 114 supra.
a)/pleton: a standing epithet of xruso/s; cp. 1. 14, 50, 215, 3. 106 (also with oi/mwgh/ 6. 58, 8. 99, c. 24 supra, u(/dwr 8. 12, a(/les 4. 53)—‘gold beyond the dreams of avarice,’ gold galore.

strato/n seems the least likely to appeal to a lady: what would she do with it? Perhaps it is only introduced for the sake of the next learned remark. Or were Persian princesses too titular colonels at times?
didoi=, ‘is giving,’ ‘gives,’ seems a little weak after the e)di/dou just above: a perfect or pluperfect here would do nicely.
punqa/netai: by hearsay.
maqou=sa: by native wit; she did not, however, quite get at the facts.
to\ poieu/menon: cp. c. 22 supra.

th=| me\n ou)k ei)=xe e)/gkoton: she did not (presumably) suspect the intrigue between Xerxes and Artaynta (the younger), their son's bride, but thought perhaps that his visits to the daughter covered an intrigue with the mother, and that the mother had bestowed the fa=ros on the daughter. She therefore planned the destruction of the wife of Masistes. The curtain descends upon the third act of this tragedy.
e)/gkoton: 8. 29 supra.
h(\ de/, ‘but she <*>’ the resumed subject annexes the particle, cp. c. 109. 13 supra.
e)lpi/zousa: rather ‘believing’ than ‘hoping,’ cp. Index, sub v.

tau=ta e)kei/nhn prh/ssein, ‘that she was at the bottom of the whole business’ —‘intrigue.’ The e)kei/nhn is no more, strictly speaking, necessary than the h(/ just before, but its introduetion makes for emphasis and lucidity. prh/ssein as above.

fula/casa de\ protiqe/menon, ‘she waited her own husband's holding a royal feast,’ i.e. a royal feast held by her own husband Xerxes. fula/ssein, cp.
1. 48 fula/cas th\n kuri(hn tw=n h(mere/wn. dei=pnon proti/qesqai, of the king: cp. cei/nia proqei=nai 7. 29.

th=| e)ge/neto <o(> basileu/s, ‘on the king's birthday’: a strong e)ge/neto, cp. 1, 133 th=| e)kastos e)ge/neto. (Not a mere Accession celebration, on the day when he became king!) <o(> basileu/s, sc. o) a)ei\ b. 1. 133 illustrates the importance of birthday feasts among the Persians, who were no pessimists (like Thrakians, cp. 5. 4).
tukta/: tacht; not from tukto/s. The interesting philological note, even if from Hdt.'s own pen, will not convince any one that Hdt. was deeply versed in Persian; cp. 8. 85 supra.

th\n kefalh\n sma=tai: cp. 4. 73 smhsa/menoi ta\s kefala/s (e)ksma=n 3. 148). The meaning here must be that on his birthday and on his birthday alone (to/te mou=non) the king appears without his tiara, or crown (Stein), his hair glistening with the oil of gladness.

deino/n te kai\ a)na/rsion e)poie/eto, ‘thought it shocking and monstrous’ (a)na/rsios c. 37 supra), for two reasons: tou=to me/n, to hand over his brother's wife to certain torture and death (he knew what was in store for her); tou=to de/, she being innocent in the whole affair.

sunh=ke ga\r tou= ei(/neken e)de/eto, ‘he knew with what object she was making the request of him.’ There had probably been previous words on the subject between Amestris and Xerxes. sunh=ka is the Attic form (Ep. cune/hka). e)de/eto, cp. 8. 3.
lipareou/shs: c. 45 supra.

u(po\ tou= no/mou e)cergo/menos: cp. a/nagkai/h| e)ce/rgomai 7. 96, 139 supra. As to the no/mos, Xerxes was not equal to the occasion, or his sages and councillors would have come to the rescue; cp. the Response of the Royal Justices 3. 31, tw=| basileu/onti *perse)wn e)cei=nai poie/ein to\ a)\n bou/lhtai. The two cases are not, indeed, precisely the same; but the moral is that the king was not bound by any law. Besides, to\n xrhi/zonta (masc.) might have given them a loophole!
a)tuxh=sai, ‘to fail’; the opposite of tuxei=n, cp. c. 108 supra.
sfi: sc. toi=si *pe/rsh|si.
dunato/n: fas, 7. 149 supra. ‘O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great kings’ (Henry V. v. ii. 293). But Custom still was king o'the king of kings! Cp. 3. 38.
kataneu/ei, frequent in Homer, but rare in prose (Plato, Rep. 350 E, seems to use the word literally. Here it may be used metaphorically, ‘assents’).

poie/ei w(=de o(\ de/: the curtain rises upon the last act of the tragedy; the desperate effort of Xerxes to make things right with his brother, the barbarities of Amestris in her revenge, the splendid crime of Masistes, and the doom that just anticipates his treasonable success. o(\ de/, cp. c. 108. 13 supra.
poie/ein after poie/ei is rather thin.
*darei/ou: i.e. the son of Hystaspes. (Atossa is not mentioned, but cp. 7. 82.)
ei)=s a)nh\r a)gaqo/s: more, perhaps, than he could say for all his brothers. Masistes could scarcely have returned the compliment with truth.

di/dwmi qugate/ra th\n e)mh/n, ‘I offer you my daughter,’ in marriage; she is, therefore, niece to Masistes. Such near marriages were not illegal even in Sparta (cp. 7. 239 supra), much less in polygamous Persia.
e)/xeis: e)/xe, ‘have to wife’; cp. 7. 61. 13.
doke/ei, ‘seems good.’
a)poqwma/sas, ‘when he had recovered from his astonishment’; cp. 8. 65 supra.
a)/xrhston: a meiosis, ‘injurious,’ inexpedient.

au)th/ te/ moi kata\ no/on e)ou=sa: cp. the story of Anaxandridas 5. 39, who was allowed to retain his first wife. Masistes might be puzzled in Peisia to know why marrying the king's daughter should involve putting away his first wife (and might have suspeeted Xerxes of too personal an interest in the matter); but even in the Harem there is a chief wife or sultana, and this fact is perhaps taken for granted in the story.
gh=mai, of the bridegroom (ghmasqai, of the bride; e.g. 4. 117).
mega/la me\n poieu=mai, ‘account it greatness,’ ‘am highly lionoured’; the plural is observable, cp. 1. 119 mega/la poihsa/menos.
mhdamw=s biw= deo/menos, ‘do not press (insist on) thy request.’
pe/prhktai: ita sane (ou(/tw) actum est de te (Baehr); igitur hoc profecisti (Schweighaeuser); deine Sache steht jetzt so (Stein, taking ou(/tw to refer to what follows).
w(s ma/qh|s ta\ dido/mena de/kesqai, ‘that you may learn to accept what is offered to you.’ This must be almost a proverbial expression; cp. 8. 26, 137 supra.
ei)/pas toso/nde e)xw/ree e)/cw, ‘all he said before going out was . .’

ou) dh/ kou/ me a)pw/lesas; ‘can it be thou hast undone me?’ The v.l. kw gives a good sense: nondum sane me perdidisti (Baehr); ‘thou hast not yet taken my life’ (Rawlinson), i.e. there is still fight left in me; I am not at the end of my resources (of course with a period, not an interrogative); this well accords with the sequel.

e)n de\ tou/tw| ktl.: the second pitiless scene in this act of the tragedy: non tamen intus | digna geri promes in scaenam, multaque tolles | ex oculis, quae mox narret facundia praesens (Hor. de A. p. 182 ff.). What a meeting between the faithful wife and her fond husband! What vows of vengeance by the stalwart sons, what tears and lamentation of the daughters, over the mother's dying bed! What self-reproaches of the guilty one before her self-inflicted end! It is in a way strange that no Greek playwright ever utilized the material lying to his hand in the pages of Hdt.
dialumai/netai: the simple verb lumai/nesqai is common, cp. 8. 28 supra; the prep., of course, strengthens it. The perfect part. infra is passive.

tou/s te mazou/s: cp. 4. 202. If the a)potamou=sa is taken to extend down as far as xei/lea, and the e)ktamou=sa as applying only to glw=ssan, there is grammatically an asyndeton; probably the kai/ after proe/bale connects that verb with a)pope/mpei and e)ktamou=sa ‘governs’ r(i=na, w)=ta, xei/lea as well as glw=ssan. But the sentence is unsightly from every point of view. It sounds barbarous, savage, unhellenic enough; but it curiously resembles the threat of Antinoos to Iros, Od. 18. 84 ff. pe/myw s' h)/peiro/nde, balw\n e)n nhi\ melai/nh|, | ei)s *)/exeton basilh=a, brotw=n dhlh/mona pa/ntwn, o(/s k) a)po\ r(i=na ta/mh|si kai\ ou(/ata nhle/i xalkw=|, | mh/dea/ t' e)ceru/sas dw/h| kusi\n w)ma\ da/sasqai.
a)khkow\s e)lpo/menos: the former participle is clearly stronger than a/kou/sas, the latter is clearly not ‘hoping.’

diefqarme/nhn, ‘utterly ruined’ (but not necessarily ‘dead’); cp. 1. 34 ou(/teros me
 die/fqarto, h)=n ga dh\ kwfo/s, 38 to
 ga dh\ e(/teron diefqarme/non th
 a/koh
 ou)k ei)=nai/ moi logi/zomai. But obviously the miserable woman could not long survive such treatment.

au)ti/ka meta\ tau=ta introduces the last scene (shifted to Baktria), where, after conspiring with his sons, Masistes raises the flag of revolt in his satrapy, and falls, his brave boys fighting round him, at the head of an army of devoted adherents, in battle against the all too loyal subjects of the feeble tyrant.

*ba/ktra, the city of Balkh, capital of the *ba/ktrios nomo/s, or Baktrian satrapy (3. 93), of which he was governor (u(/parxos tw=n *baktri/wn = *baktrianw=n l.c.). The city is mentioned 6. 9 (as a sort of ultima Thule of the Persian Empire from the Greek point of view; but cp. 4. 204). On the Baktrians cp. 7. 64 supra, where the *sa/kai are associated with them, as here.

ta/ per a)
 kai\ e)ge/neto, but did not, for Xerxes took measures to crush him. Hdt. implies that Masistes did not reach Baktra, or the Baktrian land, but was overtaken on the way thither, and came to an end. The mention of his army, however (kai\ th
 stratih
 th
 e)kei/nou), seems hardly consistent with that view, which is also not in itself probable; Masistes and his sons would have reached Baktria long before the army collected and sent against them by Xerxes. Hdt. is led into the inconsistency and error apparently by his own notion (w(s e)moi\ doke/ein) that, if Masistes had once succeeded in raising a revolt in Baktria, he would have wrought the king no end of woe; in other words, the ease with which Masistes was suppressed convinced Hdt. that he had not actually raised a rebellion in Baktria, and as the Baktrians were devoted to Masistes, he cannot have reached Balkh, or he would have raised a rebellion.

Probably Masistes, as satrap of Baktria, did raise the province, and fell fighting at the head of the eastern levies of the empire. The gruesome story just related was an attempt to explain the cause of the revolt in terms acceptable to Hellenic romance. There may have been a set of more political factors at work. There was a constant possibility in the Achaimenid Empire of a rupture between the eastern and western halves, the Iranian highland, and the older centres and areas of secular civilization The weakness of Xerxes, and the ignominious failure of the European expedition, were calculated to provoke disloyalty. Masistes, his brother, was but re-enacting the rôle of Bardiya, the son of Kyros the Great; Xerxes, or his servants, succeeded, as Kambyses, or again as Dareios had succeeded, in reasserting the unity of the empire. Masistes, who like Xerxes himself united both strains in the Achaimenid pedigree (cp. 7. 11 supra), was a very formidable Pretender, and a far better man evidently than his brother. Rawlinson (ad l.) seems to underestimate the possibilities of a Baktrian secession, or Home-rule movement, though he is justified in correcting the excesses of Blakesley in the other direction. The loyalty of the Baktrians to Dareios and their general loyalty to the Achaimenid
House (based upon the argumentum a silentio) might not prevent their preferring a Masistes to a Xerxes. The failure of Masistes in the end may have been due to the fact that the flower of the Baktrians had been culled by Mardonios (cp. 8. 113 supra), and their bones were now enriching the plain of Boiotia. The exact date of Masistes' attempt is problematic; but it falls, no doubt, into the Pentekontaeteris.

e)k *muka/lhs: in c. 106 supra the Greeks have been conveyed from Mykale back to Samos, and have started from Samos for the Hellespont. Moreover, it was only at Samos (according to that passage) that they had decided on their policy.
o(rmhqe/ntes, of physical motion (cp. 7. 37. 6, 7).

*lekto/n: the position of Lekton is more nearly indicated by Thucydides 8 101. 3. It is the SW. corner of the Troad, the extreme projection of Mount Ida (as is implied even in Homer, Il. 14. 283-4), now Cape Baba, or Sta. Maria— the most westerly point of the continent of Asia.
o(/rmeon, though from another verb, is not very happy in juxtaposition. Cp. o(/rmeon o(rmw/menoi 7. 22. 3, 4.

a)polamfqe/ntes, intercepti (Valla); cp. 2. 115. Wesseling compares Livy 37. 37 Eumenes rex, conatus primo ab Hellesponto reducere classem in hiberna Elaeam, adversis deinde ventis quum aliquot diebus superare Lecton promontorium non potuisset, in terram egressus in castra Romana (ad caput Caici am<*>is) cum parva manu contendit. But Eumenes (in 190 B.C.) was going from the Hellespont to the Caicus; the Greeks in 479 B.C. from Samos to the Hellespont. Violent north, or west, winds would have held them up: would wind from any quarter but the south have hindered Eumenes? (Perhaps the west? zefu/rou te kai\ no/tou ei(/neka 7. 36 supra.)
*)/abudon: cp. 8. 130, etc. As to the bridges, and the policy of going to the Hellespont, cp. c. 106 supra.

e)/doce, ‘Leotychidas and his Peloponnesian following decided . .’ a)mfi/, cp. c. 69 supra; with e)/doce contr. e)do/kee c. 106 supra. Stein (ad l.) understands Thuc. 1. 90 to represent Leotychidas and the Peloponnesians as going straight home from Samos; but the case is not quite clear. Thucydides does not, indeed, expressly record the removal to the Hellespont; but neither does he expressly say that it was Samos wherefrom the Peloponnesians returned; he merely says, the Peloponnesians returned, the Athenians remained. On this point there is no contradiction between Hdt. and Thuc.

*)aqhnai/oisi de\ kai\ *canqi/ppw|, ‘the Athenians and their strategos, Xanthippos,’ decided to remain and attempt the recovery of the Chersonese. Hdt. does not make clear, what Thuc. l.c. expressly records, that the new allies— oi( a)p' *)iwni/as kai\ *(ellhspo/ntou cu/mmaxoi, h)/dh a)festhko/tes a)po\ basile/ws—remained with the Athenians and assisted them. Xanthippos is here named for the first time since 8. 131 (but without his patronymic); not much credit is given him for the victory of Mykale.
au)tou=: not quite strictly ‘on the spot,’ for they move across to Sestos; it refers perhaps rather to ‘the Hellespont’ than to ‘Abydos’

u(pome/nein has four meanings or uses in Hdt. (a) ‘To remain behind,’ as here; cp. to\ u(pome/non e)n *spa/rth| 7. 209. (b) ‘To await, sustain, an attack,’ a defensive attitude; cp. 4. 3 ou)k u(pomene/ousi (as enemies, cp. 7. 101, 120, and c. 23 supra). (c) Simply ‘to await’ (as a friend), 3. 9 u(pe/mene e)nqau=ta to\n *kambu/sew strato/n (as friends). (d) Absolutely, ‘to abide,’ to survive; 4. 149 ou) ga\r u(pe/meinan ta\ te/kna.

th\n *xerso/nhson: the Chersonese ‘on the Hellespont’ last mentioned 7. 58 (cp. 7. 33. 3, where it should have been noted that the name had occurred previously c. 22. 3 without further speeification, a fact pointing to the independence of the two passages). Thucydides speaks of it always, like Hdt. here, simply as ‘the Chersonese.’ Our oldest authority for the designation h) *qra|ki/a *xerro/nhsos appears to be Strabo 92, etc. Cp. 6. 33 supra.

*shsto/n: last mentioned in 7. 78; cp. 7. 33. It was an old possession of the Athenians; cp. 4. 143, and 6. 34, etc. Sestos was, or was to be made, frou/rion kai\ fulakh\ tou= panto\s *(ellhspo/ntou (cp. Thue. 8. 62. 3).
tau/thn: there was only one Sestos; the demonstrative is purely stylistic, referring to the previous nomination.
w(s e)o/ntos, ‘it being . .’ as a matter of fact (cp. w(s ou) pareo/ntos au)tou= 8. 69 supra); the gender is determined by tei/xeos.

sunh=lqon: sc. oi( peri/oikoi (cp. tw=n perioiki/dwn), or, more probably, a)/ndres *pe/rsai, out of a)nh(r *pe/rshs below, just as a)lle/wn sc. poli/wn out of po/lios. But has a word or two dropped out before kai\ dh\ kai/? (Cp. cc. 101. 14, 102. 6 supra.)
*kardi/hs: cp. 7. 58 supra.
*oi)o/bazos: on this name cp. 7. 68 supra.

e(nqau=ta h)=n kekomikw/s: is this expression merely equivalent to e)nqau=ta e)kekomi/kei? If so, why not e)kei=se instead of e)nqau=ta? The substantive or auxiliary verb has at least affected the adverb! But e)nqau=ta h)=n is a complete statement in itself, save that ta\ [e)k] tw=n gefure/wn o(/pla demands a governing verb. Moreover, e)nqau=ta might = e)n *kardi/h| if h)=n k. simply = e)kekomi/kei. In fine h)=n kekomikw/s is not a mere temporal pluperfect, used indifferently with the thematic form, or the aorist: it records an action, past indeed, but of still abiding effect. In this case perhaps even something more: ‘he was in Sestos whither he had conveyed the ropes.’

tau/thn: sc. th\n *shsto\n tau/thn supra. ‘Aiolians of the locality’ were in actual possession of the town, but
the garrison included Persians and a good crowd of allies ‘as well’ (a)/llwn, cp. 8. 55. 5).

e)pixw/rioi *ai)ole/es: i.e. Aiolians on the European side, in distinction to those of Aiolis proper (cp. 7. 95 supra). Ainos (7. 58) was an ‘Aiolian’ town, like Sestos (also Alopekonnesos, Skymn. 705).

e)tura/nneue de\ tou/tou tou= nomou=. This nomo/s, a European, a Thrakian province, is not reckoned in the list of satrapies 3. 89-94 (which is ex hypothesi valid for the year 520 B.C.), but it must have been constituted by Dareios about 512 B.C. (cp. 4. 143 and 7. 105 supra), though it may have been temporarily lost during the Ionic Revolt (498-493 B.C.) and only recovered shortly before Marathon (cp. 6. 40, 41, 104). The verb looks as though it might carry a ‘dyslogistic’ intention here (“richtiger e)petro/peue,” Stein, as in 7. 78). The satrap was specifically *ce/rcew u(/parxos, having been actually appointed by him; he is described in 7. 35 as *shstou= u(/parxos. Sestos being no doubt the residence of the governor. This variation is one of several observations in this case, which prove once more with how much insouciance Hdt. works from various sources in different contexts.

*)artau/kths might never have been mentioned before! In 7. 33 supra his fate has already been related—and this passage consequently discounted. In 7. 78 he has figured as one of the a)/rxontes in the army-list, and his patronymic is there supplied (o( *xera/smios). The first passage is probably a late insertion. The army-list is, of course, sui generis. The present passage may well be of the original draft of the Book, i.e. of older composition than 7. 33.

deino\s de\ kai\ a)ta/sqalos: not what might have been expected of a Persian? a)ta/sqalos 7. 35, 8. 109 supra. He was also something of a humourist, to judge by the sequel. o(\s kai/ oddly enough reappears 7. 33.

basile/a e)lau/nonta e)p' *)aqh/nas: not much reliance is to be placed on this chronological index, nor indeed upon the anecdote which it introduces; but the phrase clearly betrays the Attic or Atticizing source of the story, making Athens the goal of the king's march.

e)chpa/thse u(pelo/menos: an inverted predication; in reality, after and by deceiving the king he filched away the objects of value. It is not necessarily implied that otherwise Xerxes would have taken them himself: rather, (that) the king was the natural patron and protector of the shrine. There is a comical contradiction between Blakesley and Rawlinson at this point:
B. ii. 492. “The contrast between the reckless proceedings of Artayctes and the tenderness of Xerxes for religious institutions of exactly the same character as the Protesilaos — worship (see 7. 43) is not to be overlooked.”
R. iv.3 462. “It harmonised with the general designs of Xerxes, who had no real tenderness for the Greek religion, but sought to depress and disgrace it in every possible way (vide supra 8. 33. 35. 53 etc.).”

In fact both observations are somewhat beside the mark, and ascribe too conscious and politic an attitude to Xerxes in the question of Religion and Greek Religion. A good deal of the apparent evidence on the subject is afterthought and reflexion, which glorified the war by lending it a religious or quasi-religious halo; cp. note to 8. 109. 15.

*prwtesi/lew tou= *)ifi/klou. Protesilaos led to Troy the men of Phylake, Pyrasos, Iton, Antron, Ptelion, leaving a wife and half-built house behind him in Phylake. First of all Achaians he leaped ashore, and was felled in the very act by a Dardan, Iliad (2. 695-702). At home in Phylake he was worshipped (as a hero): *prwtesi/la, to\ teo\n d' a)ndrw=n *)axaiw=n e)n *fula/ka| te/menos sumba/llomai, Pindar, Isth. 1. 58. And in the Thrakian Chersonese his tomb (ta/fos) was to be seen, close to Elaiûs; cp. Thuc. 8. 102. 3 to\ i(ero\n tou= *prwtesila/ou, Strabo 595 to\ *prwtesila/eion. Pausanias (1. 34. 2) appears to class him with Trophonios
(cp. 8. 138 supra) and Amphiaraos (ibid.), as all three heroes who have been apotheosized (that is of the very essenee of Polytheism, cp. A. Lyall, Asiatic Studies, pp. 20 ff.). Stein (note ad l.) asserts that he was (ohne Zweifel) a pre-Hellenic deity, in the Chersonese, identified, for some reason or other, with the Greek hero. Our own Wordsworth has made his ghost the subject of a pseudo-antique conversation in one of his best-known poems (Laodamia), the motifs of which he may have taken from Hyginus' Fabulae 103, 104. Those fables, especially the second, point to an orgiastic, or mysterious cult, proper to women, and perhaps at home in Thrace, which might in part at least explain the worst charges against Artayktes; cp. infra. Iphiklos is the father of Protesilaos and Podarkes (Iliad l.c.) and himself the son of Phylakos (ibid. 13, 698), the founder of Phylake. According to the myth in Od. 11. 281-297 he was the owner of beeves, that Neleus was bent on getting stolen, and the would-be cattle-lifter was caught and kept a year in bonds by the might of Iphiklos. These things may be in part an allegory; cp. note to c. 93. 3 supra.
*)elaiou=ntos: cp. 7. 22 supra. The shrine was evidently a wealthy one (ta\ xrh/mata, objeets of value, cp. 8. 35. 8).

e)sti\ h)=n: a designed contrast, the ‘tomb’ and ‘temenos’ existing in Hdt.'s own day (as in Thucydides', 8. 102, 3), the objects of value having been carried off by Artayktes. Below, a i(ro/n and an a)/duton are further implied.
di/khs kurh/sas does not imply actual judicial proceedings.
tis, as in 8. 109.

a)ndro/s is of course emphatic; Artayktes, deino\s kai\ a)ta/sqalos, had implicitly denied the divinity and the heroism of Protesilaos. Xerxes would not have granted him his request had he known that the tomb of a hero, the temple of a god, was in question. u(potophqe/nta is from the deponent u(potope/omai, cp. 6. 70.

e)pi\ gh=n de\ th
 basile/os strateu/esqai. Hdt. considers it in no way necessary to explain further or account for Protesilaos: his name and story were familiar to all Hellenes. The Persian assumption of an immemorial sovranty over Asia is well illustrated supra 7. 11
*pe/loy o( *fru/c, e)w
 pate/rwn tw=n e)mw=n dou=los ktl. Cp. 1. 4 th
 ga *)asi/hn kai\ ta\ e)noike/onta e)/qnea oi)khieu=ntai oi( *pe/rsai.
e)/lege noe/wn, ‘in saying this he meant as follows.’
ai)ei/, ‘for the time being,’ ‘from time to time,’ cp. 2. 98, 168 toi=si ai)ei\ doruforou=si, c. 102 supra toi=si ai)ei\ e)spi/ptousi.

e)/speire kai\ e)ne/meto, au)to/s te ktl., he cultivated and grazed it. Blakesley interprets to mean merely that Artayktes converted the demesne and temple into a paradise and seraglio. The cult of Protesilaos was perhaps especially an orgiastic one for women. Cp. p. 823 a supra.
to/te de/: cp. c. 114 supra.
a)fu/ktws de/ kws: like fate, like Nemesis. Baehr doubts a/fu/ktws without sufficient reason: the adj. is found in Simonides, Pindar, Aischyl., Soph., Plato, etc. Cp. App. Crit.
fqino/pwron: 4. 42; Thuc. 2. 31. 1.
h)/sxallon: aegre ferebant, 3. 152.

tw=n strathgw=n. Xanthippos was not in sole command; this was perhaps the first instance of the forces of the democracy being employed through the winter and on foreign service: ‘the generals’ had perhaps a holy horror of Themistokles, who was certainly in Athens; cp. Thuc. 1. 90. 3.
pri\n h)\ e)ce/lwsi: if conditional, a)/n might be expected; if merely temporal, the infimtive. metape/myhtai, ‘recall.’
ou(/tw dh/ marks the apodosis.
ste/rgein: differently, c. 113 supra.

e)s pa=n h)/dh kakou= a)pigme/noi h)=san: cp. 7. 118 e)s p. k. a)pi/kato ou(/tw w(/ste e)gi/nonto. But a)pigme/noi h)=san here is not perhaps a mere equivalent to a)pi/kato there. The phrase here is more extensive (e.g. h)/dh). Cp. c. 115 supra.

to/nous: purely concrete, and no
doubt of leather = i(ma/ntas (5. 25). Cp. Aristoph. Lys. 923, Ekk. 533 (cp. 7. 36).
o)/pisqe tou= tei/xeos: on the side of the wall away from the Athenian lines, which did not surround the city. tw=n polemi/wn, sc. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn. Could this turn occur in an Attic source?

oi( *xersonhsi=tai: the inhabitants of the Chersonese a)po\ pase/wn tw=n poli/wn, cp. 4. 137, 6. 38, 39. (The names of upwards of forty places are recoverable, cp. Pauly-Wissowa iii. 2247 f. Of these about nine are found in Hdt., viz. *)agorh/ 7. 58, *ai)go\s potamoi/ c. 119 infra, *)elaiou=s c. 116 supra, etc., *(/ellhs ta/fos 7. 58, *kardi/h c. 115 supra, ete., *leukh\ a)kth/ 7. 25, *ma/dutos 7. 33, c. 120 infra, *paktu/h 6. 36, *shsto/s c. 114 supra, etc.)
ei)=xon, ‘mounted guard on . .,’ a very strong e)/xein.

*qrh/ikes *)ayi/nqioi: these were old enemies of the *do/logkoi *qrh/ikes, the occupants of the Chersonese (cp. 6. 34), and the wall from Kardia to Paktye was built by Miltiades I. to keep them out (ib. 36). Steph. B. sub v. *ai)=nos gives *)/ayunqos as another name; cp. 7. 58 supra. Blakesley well describes them as the Perioikoi of Ainos; cp. Strabo, 331 fr. 58, h( me
 ga *ai)=nos kei=tai kata\ th
 pro/teron *)ayunqi/da nu=n de\ *korpilikh
 legome/nhn, h( de\ tw=n *kiko/nwn e)fech=s pro\s dusin. The word Apsinthos, or Apsinthioi, belongs to the group of proper names in -nth- of which Korinthos, Zakynthos, Perinthos (in Thrace) are only the best known examples; cp. Oberhummer, Akarnanien (1887), p. 58. The termination appears on the Asianic side in names formed with -nd- (cp. Kretschmer, op. c. 293 ff.). Whatever be the positive significance of this observation, it confirms the opinion that the whole group of names belongs to a non-Greek, a prae-Hellenic population.

e)/qusan *pleistw/rw| e)pixwri/w| qew=|: this Thrakian deity is perhaps the Thrakian Ares of 5. 7. Their method of human sacrifice (tro/pw| tw=| sfete/rw|) will have differed from the rite as practised by the Tauroi (4. 103), and perhaps resembled that of the Getai, in the cult of Salmoxis (4. 94). Cp. further 7. 114. The companions of Oiobazos were put to death in another fashion, and also not as a religious sacrifice.
oi( de\ a)mfi\ to\n *)a., ‘Artayktes and his followers,’ cp. c. 114 supra.
o(rmhqe/ntes, of physical motion; cp. ibid.

katelamba/nonto o)li/gon e)o/ntes u(pe\r *ai)go\s potamw=n, ‘were overtaken while they were a little way beyond Aigospotamoi.’ The participle is not strictly necessary, and suggests itself therefore as predicative. ‘They were not far beyond Aigospotamoi when they were overtaken.’ Xenophon Hell. 2. 1. 21 describes the place as ‘opposite Lampsakos.’ Rawlinson will not allow that Aigospotamoi was more than an open
roadstead even in 405 B.C. But the coinage appears to prove the contrary; cp. Head, Hist. Num. p. 222; and perhaps the plural form of the word might support the correction. Xen. l.c., Diodor. 13. 105, Strabo 287, Plutarch. Lys. 9.
e)la/mfqhsan, ‘were captured’; cp. c. 114. 2 supra. (The aorist of the simple verb has a fuller sense than the imperfect of the verb in composition just above.)
sundh/santes, ‘after binding, or chaining them together,’ one to another.
oi( *(/ellhnes perhaps covers oi( *)aqhnai=oi kai\ oi( su/mmaxoi whose presence has not been expressly recognized.
le/getai u(po\ *xersonhsite/wn: the express notice of the source is perhaps a disclaimer of responsibility for the story of the te/ras (ter).
tari/xous (i_): cp. 4. 53 etc. The neuter form of this word (cp. L. & S.) predominates in Attic: Hdt. uses it only as masculine.
e)pa/llonto/ te kai\ h)/spairon: for pa/llesqai cp. 7. 140 supra; a/spai/rein, cp. 8. 5 supra (an Ionic word).
o(/kws, ‘as’—comparative. Contr. the uses of o(/kws above, c. 116 o(/kws a)pi/koito, c. 117 o(/kws a)pa/goien (e)de/onto).
neoa/lwtoi appears to be an hapaxlegomenon. Everything turns on this. That kippers should dance when laid on the fire is not in itself miraculous.
perixuqe/ntes: probably guards or soldiers lying round the fire; cp. 3. 12.
soi/, ‘for thy benefit’; dat. eth.

o( e)n *)elaiou=nti: it was indeed wonderful that Protesilaos in Elaiûs should reveal a sign in Sestos. He here appears as not a god himself, but a hero, dead and kippered, but with power, by help of the gods, to avenge his wrongs! (du/namin pro\s qew=n e)/xei, but cp. tw=| qew=| just below). ti/nesqai, a ti/sis clearly in order. The speech of Artayktes so far might read as a fresh evidence of his deino/ths and a)tasqali/h— even though the verb tarixeu/ein is used by Hdt. himself (2. 86 ff.), apparently without the least comic reference, for mummification. It will hardly follow from this passage that the ta/fos at Elaiûs actually contained a mummy: Artayktes speaks metaphorically.

a)/poina: cp. 6. 79. e)piqei=nai: Artayktes acts as judge and jury in his own case (cp. di/khn tau/thn e)pe/qhke 1. 120, tau/thn th\n zhmi/hn e)pe/qhkan 1. 145). He offers a fine, 100 talents, instead of the objects of value robbed from the temple (what of them? had they been
recovered and restored?), and 200 talents to be paid (a)podw/sw) to the Athenians as ransom for son and self.

to\n strathgo\n *ca/nqippon: the offer must have been conveyed to Xanthippos by the guard. Artayktes apparently could speak Greek. The men of Elaiûs, tw=| *p. timwre/ontes, cp. 8. 144. 11, demanded his execution (kataxrhsqh=nai pass., cp. kataxrh/sasqai mid. 1. 82 etc.), and the general himself inclined to the same view (no/os e)/fere, cp. 8. 100 e)/fere/ oi( h( gnw/mh).

oi(\ de\ le/gousi: no variant is recognized in 7. 33 supra. The absence of a cross reference is significant. It is remarkable that the exact scene of the crucifixion was in dispute; but that doubt did not extend to the crucifixion itself. On the a)kth/ cp. l.c. Artayktes was crucified, 7. 33 adds zw=nta, which is plainly the sense of this passage. The fate of his son (cp. c. 4 supra) is comparatively merciful; but these executions do not exhibit the ei)wqui=a prao/ths of the Demos. The victitus were perhaps handed over to the *)elaiou/sioi, or the *xersonhsi=tai, though Hdt. writes as though the Athenians present were the executioners.
e)s th\n *(ella/da: the term here seems used with a very definite and concrete geographical reference; cp. c. 101 supra.
xrh/mata: the spoils, chiefly from Mykale—where they had found qhsaurou/s tinas xrhma/twn c. 106 supra.
kai\ dh\ kai/: cp. 8. 132. 10 supra.

ta\ o(/pla tw=n gefure/wn: presumably the great cables described in 7. 36 supra. They must have been fetched from Kardia, where they had been deposited by Oiobazos c. 115 supra. Their fresh destination is not quite clear; the temples of Athens were in ruins, but the city was being rebuilt, Thuc. 1. 89. 3.

kata\ to\ e)/tos tou=to: the year here indicated could only be either the Attic civil year, or the campaigning year, from spring to spring, such as Thucydides employs after its introduction by Hdt. in the history of this very war; cp. 7.
37, 8. 131 (cp. also the history of the Triennium, Bk. 6). This consideration makes it plain that Hdt. has here in view the campaigning year 479-78 B.C. But there are nevertheless two questions which remain: (a) the date of the return of the Fleet from the Hellespont to Athens; (b) the date of the next expedition, under Pausanias, to Kypros, Thuc. 1. 94.
